title: 113_s347
content: The Act titled "First State National Historical Park Act" establishes the First State National Historical Park. Key definitions include "historical park" referring to the park itself and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. The term "State" encompasses Delaware and, for specific property, Delaware and Pennsylvania. The First State National Historical Park is established to preserve and interpret culturally significant resources related to early settlements in Delaware and Pennsylvania, as well as Delaware's role in the birth of the United States and ratification of the Constitution. The historical park will not be established until sufficient land is acquired, and a notice will be published in the Federal Register with an official boundary map available for public inspection. The Secretary may include historic sites within the boundary of the historical park as depicted on maps numbered 1 through 6. Sites such as the Old Sherriff's House, Fort Christina National Historic Landmark, Old Swedes Church National Historic Landmark, Old New Castle Courthouse, and John Dickinson Plantation may be included. The Secretary may include historic sites within the boundary of the historical park as depicted on maps numbered 1 through 6. This includes locations such as Dover Green, Ryves Holt House, The Woodlawn property, and Old New Castle Green. The administration of the historical park is outlined in Section 4. The Secretary administers the historical park in accordance with laws applicable to the National Park System, including the National Park System Organic Act and the Act of August 21, 1935. Land acquisition methods include purchase, donation, or exchange. The Secretary may acquire the "Proposed NPS Site" and "Area for Potential Addition by Donation" properties by donation, including easements or other interests in land. The Secretary may acquire land for the historical park and adjust boundaries accordingly. Interpretive tours may be provided to sites outside the park, and cooperative agreements can be made with various entities. The cooperative agreement allows institutions, nonprofits, and individuals to restore historic resources in the park with public access. The Federal share of costs is limited to 50%, and the non-Federal share can be in-kind contributions. A management plan must be developed within 3 fiscal years of receiving funds. The Secretary must complete a management plan for the historical park within 3 fiscal years of receiving funds, in accordance with applicable laws. The Secretary is required to conduct a study on additional properties in the State associated with the historical park's purposes, assessing their historical significance and potential for National Historic Landmark designation. Appropriations are authorized for the implementation of this Act. SEC. 7. OFFSET. Amends Section 7302(f) of the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 by reducing the amount authorized for appropriation by $6,500,000 if not appropriated by the date of enactment of the First State National Historical Park Act.
